list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Expand $(2x + 1)^4$ in descending powers of $x$ and simplify your
answer.
list.markScheme:
Using Pascal triangle
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/186561dc-7c53-4bef-b9cc-7a867881c1ea/images/1ac85e2d-06d7-4c46-8525-a36deed1bafc/d6143401ad9783a3554c63b7ab804d89d1d7b5f1.svg)


we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em} (2x + 1)^4 &= (2x)^4 + 4(2x)^3(1) + 6(2x)^2(1)^2 + 4(2x)(1)^3 + (1)^4 \\[9pt]
&= 16x^4 + 4(8x^3) + 6(4x^2) + 4(2x) + 1 \\[9pt]
&\answer{= 16x^4 + 32x^3 + 24x^2 + 8x + 1}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
Expand $(2x - 3)^4$ in descending powers of $x$ and simplify your
answer.
list.markScheme:
Using Pascal triangle
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/84465876-5e99-4147-a7b1-f935f18653ae/images/98735b41-0607-4876-9ea3-69cbd52fbdc8/d6143401ad9783a3554c63b7ab804d89d1d7b5f1.svg)


we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em} (2x - 3)^4 &= (2x)^4 + 4(2x)^3(-3) + 6(2x)^2(-3)^2 + 4(2x)(-3)^3 + (-3)^4 \\[9pt]
&= 16x^4 + 4(8x^3)(-3) + 6(4x^2)(9) + 4(2x)(-27) + 81 \\[9pt]
&\answer{= 16x^4 - 96x^3 + 216x^2 - 216x + 81}\end{aligned}
$$

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Consider the expansion of $(2x-1)^9$.

- Write down the number of terms in this expansion. [1]

- Find the coefficient of the term in $x^2$. [5]
list.markScheme:
- The number of terms in this expansion is
$\answer{10}$
- The term in $x^2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \binom{9}{7} \big[(2x)^{9-7}\big]\big[(-1)^7\big] &= 36\big[4x^2\big]\big[-1\big] \\[6pt]
  &= -144x^2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coefficient of the term in $x^2$
is  $\answer{-144}$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
Consider the expansion of $(x-3)^8$.

- Write down the number of terms in this expansion. [1]

- Find the coefficient of the term in $x^6$. [4]
list.markScheme:
- The number of terms in this expansion is
$\answer{9}$
- The term in $x^6$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \binom{8}{2} \big[(x)^{8-2}\big]\big[(-3)^2\big] &= 28\big[x^6\big]\big[9\big] \\[6pt]
  &= 252x^6\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coefficient of the term in $x^6$
is  $\answer{252}$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
The third term, in descending powers of $x$, in the expansion of $(x+p)^8$ is $252x^6$. Find the
possible values of $p$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em} 252x^6 &= \binom{8}{2}\big(x^{8-2}\big)\big(p^2\big) \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $p$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
252x^6 &= 28\big(x^6\big)\big(p^2\big) \\[9pt]
252 &= 28p^2 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{9.05em} \answer{p = \pm 3} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
$$

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Consider the expansion of
$\left(\dfrac{x^2}{2} + \dfrac{a}{x}\right)^6$. The constant term is
$960$.
Find the possible values of $a$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2.5em} 960 &= \binom{6}{4}\bigg[\dfrac{x^2}{2}\bigg]^{6-4}\bigg[\dfrac{a}{x}\bigg]^4 \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $a$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
960 &= 15\bigg[\dfrac{x^4}{4}\bigg]\bigg[\dfrac{a^4}{x^4}\bigg] \\[5pt]
960 &= \dfrac{15a^4}{4} \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{7.3em} \answer{a = \pm 4} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
$$

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
In the expansion of $px^2(5 + px)^8$, the coefficient of the term in
$x^6$ is $3402$. Find the value of $p$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
3402x^6 &= px^2\binom{8}{4}\big[5^{8-4}\big]\big[(px)^4\big] \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $p$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
3402x^6 &= px^2\big[70\big]\big[5^4\big]\big[p^4x^4\big] \hspace{1.5em}  \\[6pt]
3402 &= 43\hspace{0.15em}750\hspace{0.05em}p^5 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{5.3em} \answer{p =0.6} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
$$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
Consider the expansion of $\bigg(3x + \dfrac{p}{x}\bigg)^8$, where
$p > 0$. The coefficient of the term
in $x^4$ is equal to the coefficient of the term in $x^6$. Find $p$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\bigg(3x+\dfrac{p}{x}\bigg)^8 &= \sum_{k=0}^8 \binom{8}{k} \big[3x\big]^{8-k}\bigg[\dfrac{p}{x}\bigg]^k \\[3pt]
&= \sum_{k=0}^8 \binom{8}{k} \big[3^{8-k}p^k\big]\big[x^{8-2k}\big] \\
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\big[\text{coefficient of the term in $x^4$}\big] &= \big[\text{coefficient of the term in $x^6$}\big] \hspace{5.8em} \\[6pt]
\binom{8}{2}\big[3^{8-2}p^2\big] &= \binom{8}{1}\big[3^{8-1}p\big] \\[6pt]
28\big[3^6p^2\big] &= 8\big[3^7p\big] \\[12pt]
20\hspace{0.15em}412\hspace{0.05em}p^2 - 17\hspace{0.15em}496\hspace{0.05em}p &= 0 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{5.1em} \answer{p = \dfrac{6}{7}} 
 \approx 0.857... \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
$$

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
Let $f(x) = (x^2 + a)^5$.
In the expansion of the derivative, $f'(x)$, the coefficient of the term
in $x^5$ is $960$. Find the possible values of $a$.
list.markScheme:
Using the chain rule, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
f'(x) &= 5(x^2 + a)^4(2x) \\[6pt]
&= 10x(x^2 + a)^4\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, using the binomial theorem, we
have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{3em} 960x^5 &= 10x\binom{4}{2}\big[\big(x^2\big)^{4-2}\big]\big[a^2\big] \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, if we solve the equation $(1)$ for $a$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
960x^5 &= 10x\big[6\big]\big[x^4\big]\big[a^2\big] \\[6pt]
960 &= 60\hspace{0.05em}a^2 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{7.4em} \answer{a = \pm 4} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
$$

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
Consider the expansion of $\bigg(2x^6+\dfrac{x^2}{q}\bigg)^{10}$,â€†
$q \neq 0$. The coefficient of the term
in $x^{40}$ is twelve times the coefficient of the term in $x^{36}$.
Find $q$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2.5em} \bigg(2x^6+\dfrac{x^2}{q}\bigg)^{10} &= \sum_{k=0}^{10} \binom{10}{k} \big[2x^6\big]^{10-k}\bigg[\dfrac{x^2}{q}\bigg]^k \\[3pt]
&= \sum_{k=0}^{10} \binom{10}{k} \big[2^{10-k}q^{-k}\big]\big[x^{60-4k}\big] \\
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\big[\text{coefficient of the term in $x^{40}$}\big] &= 12\big[\text{coefficient of the term in $x^{36}$}\big] \hspace{2.8em} \\[6pt]
\binom{10}{5}\big[2^{10-5}q^{-5}\big] &= 12\binom{10}{6}\big[2^{10-6}q^{-6}\big] \\[6pt]
252\big[2^5q^{-5}\big] &= 12(210)\big[2^4q^{-6}\big] \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{6.9em} \answer{q = 5} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
$$

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
In the expansion of $x(2x + 1)^n$, the coefficient of the term in $x^3$
is $20n$, where $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. Find $n$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
20nx^3 &= x\binom{n}{2}\big[1^{n-2}\big]\big[(2x)^2\big] \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $n$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
20nx^3 &= x\bigg[\dfrac{n!}{2!(n-2)!}\bigg]\big[4x^2\big] \hspace{0.3em} \\[6pt]
20nx^3 &= \bigg[\dfrac{n(n-1)}{2}\bigg]\big[4x^3\big] \\[12pt]
10n &= n(n-1) \\[18pt]
0 &= n(n - 11) \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\answer{n =11} \hspace{5.7em}
$$

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
In the expansion of $(2x + 1)^n$, the coefficient of the term in $x^2$
is $40n$, where $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. Find $n$.
list.markScheme:
Using the binomial theorem, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
40nx^2 &= \binom{n}{2}\big[1^{n-2}\big]\big[(2x)^2\big] \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, solving the equation $(1)$ for $n$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
40nx^2 &= \bigg[\dfrac{n!}{2!(n-2)!}\bigg]\big[4x^2\big] \hspace{0.3em} \\[6pt]
40n &= \bigg[\dfrac{n(n-1)}{2}\bigg]\big[4\big] \\[12pt]
20n &= n(n-1) \\[18pt]
0 &= n(n - 21) \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\answer{n =21} \hspace{5.1em}
$$

list.content:
- 
  - Consider the following equation $2\binom{n}{r}=\binom{n}{r+1}$.
    Show that it can be written as $3r+2=n$.

Consider the expansion

(1+x)^n=1+a_1x+...+a_{k-1}x^{k-1}+a_{k}x^{k}+a_{k+1}x^{k+1}+...+x^n

Where $a_i \in \mathbb{Q}$ and $k \in \mathbb{Z}$.
The coefficients of three consecutive terms of the expansion are such that

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
Given that $(1 + x)^3(1 + px)^4 = 1 + qx + 93x^2 + \dots + p^4x^7$, find
the possible values of $p$ and $q$.
list.markScheme:
Using Pascal triangle
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5ede89c3-3d7f-44a4-9286-c2554a148745/images/aebac82f-9280-4cf9-ad52-e4db6b3a6da0/d6143401ad9783a3554c63b7ab804d89d1d7b5f1.svg)


we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
1 + qx + 93x^2 + \dots + p^4x^7 &= (1 + x)^3(1 + px)^4 \\[6pt]
&= \big(1 + 3x + 3x^2\hspace{-0.15em} + x^3\big)\hspace{-0.15em}\big(1 + 4px + 6p^2x^2\hspace{-0.15em} + 4p^3x^3\hspace{-0.15em} + p^4x^4\big)\end{aligned}
$$

Hence we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
qx &= 4px + 3x \hspace{2.1em} \\[6pt]
q &= 4p + 3 \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em} 93x^2 &= 6p^2x^2 + 12px^2 + 3x^2 \\[6pt] 
93 &= 6p^2 + 12p + 3 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, solving the equation $(2)$ for $p$, we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
6p^2 + 12p + 3 &= 93 \\[6pt]
6p^2 + 12p - 90 &= 0 \\[6pt]
p^2 + 2p - 15 &= 0 \\[7pt]
(p + 5)(p - 3) &= 0 \\[7pt]
p &= -5,\,3\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, substituting $p = -5,\,3$ in the
equation $(1)$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.1em} q &= 4(-5) + 3 \\[6pt]
&= -17\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.3em} q &= 4(3) + 3 \\[6pt]
&= 15\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore
$\answer{p = -5,\,q=-17}$
and  $\answer{p = 3,\,q=15}$

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
- Write down the quadratic expression $3x^2 + 5x - 2$ in the form
$(ax-b)(x+c)$.[2]

- Hence, or otherwise, find the coefficient of the term in $x^9$ in
the expansion
of $(3x^2+5x-2)^5$. [5]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{(3x - 1)(x + 2)}$
- Using the binomial theorem, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (3x^2+5x-2)^5 &= (3x-1)^5(x+2)^5 \\[6pt]
  &= \left[\sum_{k = 0}^5 \binom{5}{k}\big[(3x)^{5-k}\big]\big[(-1)^k\big]\right]\left[\sum_{k=0}^5\binom{5}{k}\big(x^{5-k}\big)\big(2^k\big)\right]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coefficient of the term in $x^9$ in the expansion of
$(3x^2+5x-2)^5$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  a_9 &= \left[\binom{5}{0}\big[3^{5-0}\big]\big[(-1)^0\big]\right]\left[\binom{5}{1}\big(2^1\big)\right] + \left[\binom{5}{1}\big[3^{5-1}\big]\big[(-1)^1\big]\right]\left[\binom{5}{0}\big(2^0\big)\right] \\[9pt]
  &= \big[(1)(3^5)(1)\big]\big[(5)(2)\big] + \big[(5)(3^4)(-1)\big]\big[(1)(1)\big] \\[15pt]
  &\answer{= 2025}\end{aligned}
  $$
